frameDefinitions: A Communicator announces (linguistically or non-linguistically) the  imminent arrival of an Individual or the occurrence of an Event.
In this frame a Traveler goes on a journey, an activity, generally planned in advance, in which the Traveler moves from a Source location to a Goal along a Path or within an Area.
A Behavior is classified as entrenched for a Protagonist or a Society.
This frame concerns Communicators communicating with each other with the aid of a Means of communication such as a telephone.
A Communicator conveys a Message to an Addressee; the Topic and Medium of the communication also may be expressed.
A Text is an entity that contains linguistic, symbolic information on a Topic, created by an Author at the Time_of_creation.
frameExamples: The unveiling of Alinghi's keel was <t>heralded</t> by alp horns
Ellen <t>journeyed</t> to Europe with five suitcases.
Let's hope it did n't have time to <t>communicate</t> any of its findings to its overlords.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Communicator</fen> greets the arrival of an <fen>Individual</fen> or occurrence of an <fen>Event</fen>.
The person who is greeted at their arrival by the <fen>Communicator</fen>.
The occurrence which is greeted by the <fen>Communicator</fen>.
The symbol-containing artifact whereby a <fen>Communicator</fen> heralds.
This role identifies the time when the <fen>Communicator</fen>  heralds.
This role identifies the place where the Communicator heralds.

This is the <fen>Area</fen> in which the traveling takes place. This frame element describes the enclosed area inside which travelling, of unspecified <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen> takes place.
The <fen>Goal</fen> is the location where the travelers end up.
The <fen>Path</fen> is the route along which the travel takes place.
This is the living being which travels. Normally, the <fen>Traveler</fen> is expressed as an external argument.
The <fen>Source</fen> is the starting point of the trip.

The <fen>Mode_of_transportation</fen> expresses how the motion of the <fen>Traveler</fen> is effected, by their body or by a vehicle which holds and conveys the <fen>Traveler</fen>. Vehicles can move in any way and in any medium. They are usually expressed obliquely with 'in' or 'by'.
The direction in which the <fen>Traveler</fen> goes.
When the traveling occurs.
The <fen>Place</fen> is the location of the motion. It describes the area in which motion (with a specified <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen>) takes place.
This Frame Element marks expressions that indicate the entrenched <fen>Behavior</fen>.
This Frame Element marks expressions that indicate whose entrenched <fen>Behavior</fen> is at issue.
This role marks expressions that indicate a region where the <fen>Behavior</fen> is  entrenched.

This role is the person who uses the <fen>Means</fen> of communication to deliver the <fen>Message</fen> to the Addressee. The Speaker is normally expressed as the External Argument of target verbs, or as the Genitive modifier of  nouns.

<fen>Addressee</fen> is the person to whom the <fen>Message</fen> is communicated. When this role is expressed, it often appears in a prepositional phrase introduced by to, or as the direct object, or as the first object in a double object construction.
This role identifies the content that the <fen>Communicator</fen> communicates to the <fen>Addressee</fen>. It can be expressed as a clause or as a noun phrase.
<fen>Topic</fen> is the subject matter to which the <fen>Message</fen> pertains. It is typically expressed as a PP Complement headed by about.

This Frame Element refers to the Instrument of Communication that is used by the <fen>Communicator</fen> (and <fen>Addressee</fen>). Each LU in this frame incorporates the <fen>Means</fen> frame element.
The sentient entity that uses language in the written or spoken modality to convey a <fen>Message</fen> to the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
<fen>Message</fen> is a proposition or set of propositions that the <fen>Communicator</fen> wants the <fen>Addressee</fen> to believe or take for granted.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the subject matter to which the <fen>Message</fen> pertains. It is normally expressed as a PP Complement headed by 'about', but in some cases it can appear as a direct object.
The physical or abstract setting in which the <fen>Message</fen> is conveyed.
The time at which the communication takes place.
The location where the act of communication occurs.
The <fen>Text</fen> is the entity that contains linguistic information. This an incorporated role for each LU in this frame.
The region where the <fen>Text</fen> is sold, circulated, or otherwise popular.
listRoleExamples: Sheep scattered from the road as trumpets heralded <fex>his arrival at the castle gates</fex>
Barney used to travel <fex>by bus </fex> a lot
<fex>His</fex> custom was to come here for the 10 o'clock service.

We can help , you to meet Egyptian people and learn about 
<fex>Egyptian</fex> customs.
They found that a loca custom <fex>in the country</fex> was to walk around barefoot at all times of the year and in all weathers .
<fex>The President</fex> cabled his assistant to cancel all of his appointments.
The President cabled <fex>his assistant</fex> to cancel all other engagements.
<fex>He</fex> finds it hard to communicate with people, not least his separated parents .
How do you communicate to them <fex>that you really like them</fex> ?
Had someone communicated to the capital <fex>about the flagrant disregard of the religious law</fex> ?
Opinions are usually communicated <fex>over the telephone</fex> and are often given within 24 hours.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: the International Telecommunications Convention of Madrid
every fifteen minutes starting on the hour
the International Telecoms Convention of Atlantic City 1947
MHz Emergency Position Indicating Radio Beacons
